HOMEWOOD. BALTIMORE. OCT. 26. 1956

Dr. Glass Backs Stevenson
Scientifically, Politically
Dr. H. Bentley Glass, professor of biology, was quoted in a
recent edition of the Baltimore
Sun as saying,"Persons who have
expressed the opinion that the
present and foreseeable rates of
nuclear test explosions hold no
genetic threat to the human race
are not considering the possible
competitive snowballing of such
tests among various nations of
the earth."
Dr. Glass said that this was an
attempt to clarify recent statements made by representatives
of two scientific groups. The
statements in question were made
by Dr. L. H. Snyder, Dean of the
Graduate School of the University of Oklahoma and Presidentelect of the American Association
for the Advancement of Sciences;
and a spokesman for the National
Academy of Sciences' Committee
on the Genetic Effects of Atomic
Radiation.
Potential Danger
Dr. Snyder stated that he believed that the radiation resulting from nuclear tests posed
enough of a potential danger to
Make international control of the
tests imperative. The spokesman
from the National Academy of
Sciences was quoted as saying
that explosions up to ten times
the extent of those which have

been made would not endanger
the human race.
"There was no real conflict
between the ideas of the two
men," said Dr. Glass. He said
that the emphasis placed on the
two statements by the press made
them appear to be in conflict.

Active Campaign
Slated For Party
By Young GOPs
Peter Putnam, acting chairman of the Young Republicans
Club, stated today that the fifteen-member organization will
actively participate in election
day campaignihg this November
6.
The group had postponed the
election of its own officers until
after election day, so that the
electioneering efforts can be directed "entirely to the Presidential and Congressional races."
The Young Republicans meet
every Monday at 4 p.m. in the
Board Room on the second floor
of Levering Hall. Professor Malcolm Moos, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, serves as senior advisor to
the club.

Dr. Moos—
Dr. Malcolm Moos, Professor
of political science at Johns Hopkins, will speak on politics, at the
Evergreen House Sunday at 3:30
p.m., in a program sponsored by
the Friends of the Johns Hopkins Library.

What young people are doing at General Electric

Young mathematician
helps pace
engineering advances
Recently General Electric developed a
compact, new motor for industrial use. But
before the motor could be put into automatic
production, one difficulty remained: to design a protective end shield that would confine any possible explosion to the motor itself.
The man who solved the tough mathematical problems involved is R.A."Pete"Powell
— a mathematical analyst whose job is to assist other engineers in math problems which
_arise in any number of different projects.
Powell's Work Is Varied and Important
Because he is not tied down to any one
project, Powell seldom has two similar assignments. Taking established engineering
and mathematical principles, some of them
extremely complicated, Powell applies them
to advanced engineering problems. In doing
this, Pete is able to make such calculations
as the distortion of a small part of a jet
engine caused by vibrations, the deflection
occurring in a turbine part when it runs at
operational speeds, or the forces exerted
• upon a rotating shaft by lubricants.

We do not intend to be scandalmongers; however,
we cannot deplore too much the practice on the part of
student leaders of failing to think problems and actions
through to logical conclusions. To reiterate, we regard the
ballot, with its blatant assumption that the individual
will dismiss his personal desires (and perhaps financial
problems?) and hence back the Ball, as a mistake.
If the Military Ball Committee is sincere in its claim
to have overlooked the right of secret ballot in a democratic society, it will take some rectifying action. An obvious move is to hold a new ballot.
One fact is clear: Whatever is done should be done
quickly if the Committee is to avoid suspicion of its
motives.

Director Of SDA

Of Campus Dems
Ted Palmer, president of the
local Students for Democratic
Action, reports that the S.D.A.
is now in the process of organizing a chapter at Goucher.
"Prospects look good," said
Palmer as he told of plans for a
joint meeting before the Thanksgiving holidays between Goucher and Hopkins S.D.A. members.
Though the S.D.A. has not had
much time for outside activities
because members are working on
the campaign, they have been
able to publish booklets on the
career of Vice-president Nixon,
which have been distributed
throughout the neighborhood
and which can be procured from
Palmer.
Activities which have been
planned for the future are a
political debate participated in
by members of the Hopkins faculty, and an election poll of
the campus, in cooperation with
Young Democrats, the
the
Young Republicans, and the
News-Letter.

Veterans Sponsor
Guidance Project
As First Program
As their first project, the newly-elected officers of the Veterans
Club have undertaken the introduction and orientation of
prospective Hopkins students to
university life.
Bob Wood, recently elected
president of the Veterans Club,
has announced that the project,
under the co-sponsorship of the
Office of Admissions, will be to
conduct high school students interested in the Hopkins through
a typical university day. The club
also plans to continue having a
social affair each month and
frequent outings, weather permitting.
One of the first duties of the
new officers Vice-president Stephen Kacala, Recording Secretary Mac Johnson, Corresponding Secretary John Cooper, and
Treasurer Bill Crout will be to
complete the "Books for Asian
Students" drive, now in its last
months.

"If we ever get on the right track, we could have the
best institutional food service in the world," Director of
Food Services Thomas C. Coulson told a meeting of the
DSRC this week.
"We have an ideal Set up; the large number of McCoy
students patronizing Levering Hall enable us to take advantage of the lower prices available to the large volume
purchaser," Mr. Coulson stated. "Most of the complaints
from the dormitory students stem from one of two causes,
both of which can be traced down to the human element.
Either our employees have been careless in a given case, or
else they haven't been trained
properly yet."
"For instance, if the pot washer leaves a little soap in a pot,
the soup tastes bad." Mr. Coulson explained that although he
had full confidence in his staff,
most of them were new at the
job. Only six members of his last
year's staff of 32 returned to his
staff. Consequently, he said,
"We're overexpanded at present.
It's hard to train new people.
It takes a person from three to
four months to get used to the
place, and to regulate his habits

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE SEVEN

BY AL FIGINSKI
Sports Editor

Capitalizing on two Hopkins mistakes to garner all
their points, Haverford dealt the men of John Bridgers
their second gridiron defeat last Saturday at Homewood.
Even in defeat the Jays looked the part of a vastly
Improved team, probably the strongest since Bridgers
took the helm in 1953. Most of the Jays who saw action
deserve credit for the all out effort which was displayed.
The play of Ken McGraw, Jerry Carr, Harry Warfield,
Dick Auffarth, and the defensive line as a whole was
Particularly outstanding.
Now the Jays face the difficult task of getting themselves "up" for tomorrow's crucial clash with the MasonDixon pacesetters, Randolph-Macon, at Ashland, Virginia. These teams are the only undefeated squads in the
M-D loop and it is
likely that the winner of tomorrow's
contest will eventually gain the league diadem.
Throughout the season the Jays have been hampered
by forward pass ineffectiveness both offensively and defensively. While this inept pass work may be an important factor in tomorrow's game, this corner believes that
the Jays have an excellent chance to return from -their
venture into Virginia with their second M-D victory.

Led by the scoring of Brenton
Woessner, the Blue Jay Frosh
soccer squad opened their season
on a bright note by defeating
Towson State Teachers JV, 2-0,
on the losers field Tuesday afternoon.
The Jays scored twice in the
first half while blanking the
Teachers throughout the contest. Woessner tallied once in the
first period and then counted
again shortly before half-time

ETS To Give
Test Groups
The Educational Testing Service will administer two groups of
examinations this fall and winter to students planning to enter graduate and professional
schools, according to Registrar
Irene Davis.
The first group will be given
to_students planning to do graduate work in the sciences, education, social sciences, languages, philosophy, mathematics or
literature. These tests will be administered at Johns Hopkins and
Morgan State College on four, as
yet unannounced, Saturdays.
The second group of examinations, entitled The Medical College Admission Test, will be
given for the final time on October 30. Both the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine and the
University of Maryland School
of Medicine are offering this test
to applicants for admission of
medical school in the fall of the
1957-1958 term.
Each test in the first group of
examinations is divided into two
Parts: a morning Aptitude test
and an afternoon Advanced test.
Except for French and Spanish,
the advanced tests are three
hours long.

HOMEWOOD. BALTIMORE. OCT. 26. 1956

Dr. Glass Backs Stevenson
Scientifically, Politically
Dr. H. Bentley Glass, professor of biology, was quoted in a
recent edition of the Baltimore
Sun as saying,"Persons who have
expressed the opinion that the
present and foreseeable rates of
nuclear test explosions hold no
genetic threat to the human race
are not considering the possible
competitive snowballing of such
tests among various nations of
the earth."
Dr. Glass said that this was an
attempt to clarify recent statements made by representatives
of two scientific groups. The
statements in question were made
by Dr. L. H. Snyder, Dean of the
Graduate School of the University of Oklahoma and Presidentelect of the American Association
for the Advancement of Sciences;
and a spokesman for the National
Academy of Sciences' Committee
on the Genetic Effects of Atomic
Radiation.
Potential Danger
Dr. Snyder stated that he believed that the radiation resulting from nuclear tests posed
enough of a potential danger to
Make international control of the
tests imperative. The spokesman
from the National Academy of
Sciences was quoted as saying
that explosions up to ten times
the extent of those which have

been made would not endanger
the human race.
"There was no real conflict
between the ideas of the two
men," said Dr. Glass. He said
that the emphasis placed on the
two statements by the press made
them appear to be in conflict.

Active Campaign
Slated For Party
By Young GOPs
Peter Putnam, acting chairman of the Young Republicans
Club, stated today that the fifteen-member organization will
actively participate in election
day campaignihg this November
6.
The group had postponed the
election of its own officers until
after election day, so that the
electioneering efforts can be directed "entirely to the Presidential and Congressional races."
The Young Republicans meet
every Monday at 4 p.m. in the
Board Room on the second floor
of Levering Hall. Professor Malcolm Moos, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, serves as senior advisor to
the club.

p.m., in a program sponsored by
the Friends of the Johns Hopkins Library.
DR. H. BENTLEY GLASS

Frosh To Choose Officers;
Petitions Required Today
The Student Council Election
Committee announced this week
that the elections for the officers of the Class of 1960 will be
held on November 12-13 in Gilman Post Office 8-4 and in the
Dormitory Dining Room 5-6.
Petitions were issued beginning October 19 to those freshmen who were interested in obtaining a post on the Freshman

What young people are doing at General Electric

Young mathematician
helps pace
engineering advances
Recently General Electric developed a
compact, new motor for industrial use. But
before the motor could be put into automatic
production, one difficulty remained: to design a protective end shield that would confine any possible explosion to the motor itself.
The man who solved the tough mathematical problems involved is R.A."Pete"Powell
— a mathematical analyst whose job is to assist other engineers in math problems which
_arise in any number of different projects.
Powell's Work Is Varied and Important
Because he is not tied down to any one
project, Powell seldom has two similar assignments. Taking established engineering
and mathematical principles, some of them
extremely complicated, Powell applies them
to advanced engineering problems. In doing
this, Pete is able to make such calculations
as the distortion of a small part of a jet
engine caused by vibrations, the deflection
occurring in a turbine part when it runs at
operational speeds, or the forces exerted
• upon a rotating shaft by lubricants.

Ted Palmer, president of the
local Students for Democratic
Action, reports that the S.D.A.
is now in the process of organizing a chapter at Goucher.
"Prospects look good," said
Palmer as he told of plans for a
joint meeting before the Thanksgiving holidays between Goucher and Hopkins S.D.A. members.
Though the S.D.A. has not had
much time for outside activities
because members are working on
the campaign, they have been
able to publish booklets on the
career of Vice-president Nixon,
which have been distributed
throughout the neighborhood
and which can be procured from
Palmer.
Activities which have been
planned for the future are a
political debate participated in
by members of the Hopkins faculty, and an election poll of
the campus, in cooperation with
Young Democrats, the
the
Young Republicans, and the
News-Letter.

Veterans Sponsor
Guidance Project
As First Program
As their first project, the newly-elected officers of the Veterans
Club have undertaken the introduction and orientation of
prospective Hopkins students to
university life.
Bob Wood, recently elected
president of the Veterans Club,
has announced that the project,
under the co-sponsorship of the
Office of Admissions, will be to
conduct high school students interested in the Hopkins through
a typical university day. The club
also plans to continue having a
social affair each month and
frequent outings, weather permitting.
One of the first duties of the
new officers Vice-president Stephen Kacala, Recording Secretary Mac Johnson, Corresponding Secretary John Cooper, and
Treasurer Bill Crout will be to
complete the "Books for Asian
Students" drive, now in its last
months.

eleven children of Polish immigrant parents, was born in Jersey City, New Jersey, on July

BY AL FIGINSKI
Sports Editor

Capitalizing on two Hopkins mistakes to garner all
their points, Haverford dealt the men of John Bridgers
their second gridiron defeat last Saturday at Homewood.
Even in defeat the Jays looked the part of a vastly
Improved team, probably the strongest since Bridgers
took the helm in 1953. Most of the Jays who saw action
deserve credit for the all out effort which was displayed.
The play of Ken McGraw, Jerry Carr, Harry Warfield,
Dick Auffarth, and the defensive line as a whole was
Particularly outstanding.
Now the Jays face the difficult task of getting themselves "up" for tomorrow's crucial clash with the MasonDixon pacesetters, Randolph-Macon, at Ashland, Virginia. These teams are the only undefeated squads in the
M-D loop and it is
likely that the winner of tomorrow's
contest will eventually gain the league diadem.
Throughout the season the Jays have been hampered
by forward pass ineffectiveness both offensively and defensively. While this inept pass work may be an important factor in tomorrow's game, this corner believes that
the Jays have an excellent chance to return from -their
venture into Virginia with their second M-D victory.

Blue Jay Frosh Booters
Blank Towson In Opener
Led by the scoring of Brenton
Woessner, the Blue Jay Frosh
soccer squad opened their season
on a bright note by defeating
Towson State Teachers JV, 2-0,
on the losers field Tuesday afternoon.
The Jays scored twice in the
first half while blanking the
Teachers throughout the contest. Woessner tallied once in the
first period and then counted
again shortly before half-time

soccer letterman, stated that he
could not predict anything for
the team, but added that he was
pleased with the squad.

ETS To Give
Test Groups
The Educational Testing Service will administer two groups of
examinations this fall and winter to students planning to enter graduate and professional
schools, according to Registrar
Irene Davis.
The first group will be given
to_students planning to do graduate work in the sciences, education, social sciences, languages, philosophy, mathematics or
literature. These tests will be administered at Johns Hopkins and
Morgan State College on four, as
yet unannounced, Saturdays.
The second group of examinations, entitled The Medical College Admission Test, will be
given for the final time on October 30. Both the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine and the
University of Maryland School
of Medicine are offering this test
to applicants for admission of
medical school in the fall of the
1957-1958 term.
Each test in the first group of
examinations is divided into two
Parts: a morning Aptitude test
and an afternoon Advanced test.
Except for French and Spanish,
the advanced tests are three
hours long.

Dr. Eisenhower Answers Student Q ems
Covering University And Political Subjects
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower,
president of the Johns Hopkins
University, answered seventeen
questions posed by undergraduates since his arrival at Homewood in a filled-to-capacity
Shriver Hall assembly last Friday.
The following are the seventeen queries and Dr. Eisenhower's answers:
1 and 2) Will Hopkins grow in
size, and what is Hopkins place
in the field of education? Dr.
the
applauded
Eisenhower
growth in size and quality of
public colleges, noting it was
"imperative" because of the
changing society which demands
a "high level of education." But,
he said, "There is no such obligation on a private university,"
and emphasized that he "would
think that the original basis of
John Hopkins University applies
today," namely that "the highest
level of education" can be fulfilled by its small size.
3) What is the importance of
undergraduate work in relation to graduate work? "Undergraduate work is important and
vital in itself," said Dr. Eisenhower, adding that he will "always uphold and foster undergraduate programs as valuable
in themselves and as preparation
for graduate level work."
4) What is your definition of
education? Education was defined as training in "how to
think objectively and creatively
within a moral framework," and
must be concerned with the "intellectual, physical and spiritual
maturing" of those who pursue
it.
5) How much freedom should
student government be allowed?
